question: If <katex>$A=\begin{bmatrix}1&\tan \alpha/2\\ -\tan \alpha/2&1\end{bmatrix}$</katex> and <katex>$AB=I$</katex> then <katex>$B=$</katex>
explanation: <katex>$\text{adj} A = \begin{bmatrix}1&-\tan \alpha/2\\ \tan \alpha/2&1\end{bmatrix} = A^T$</katex> (Note: The transpose of A has signs flipped on off-diagonals compared to A, wait. <katex>$A = \begin{bmatrix}1&t\\ -t&1\end{bmatrix}$</katex>. <katex>$A^T = \begin{bmatrix}1&-t\\ t&1\end{bmatrix}$</katex>. Adjoint swaps diagonals (1,1) and negates off-diagonals (-t, -(-t)=t). Yes, <katex>$\text{adj} A = A^T$</katex>.)
